course.title: Computer Science for Non-Technical Users
course.subtitle: Learn CS fundamentals to effectively use AI tools for building automations, prototypes, and applications
course.description: A comprehensive course designed for non-technical users who want to understand computer science concepts to better leverage AI tools for development, automation, and product-building.
learningObjectives: Understand abstraction and system thinking for better AI prompting
Master data structures (JSON, lists, objects) for automation tools
Learn API concepts for integrating AI with other services
Develop mental models for client-server architecture
Apply CS concepts to real-world AI and automation scenarios

modules.title: Understanding Abstraction
modules.description: Learn to think in layers - the foundation of system thinking

content.introduction: Abstraction is the foundational concept in system thinking. It means breaking down complex systems into layers, allowing you to reason about what something does without needing to immediately understand how it does it.
keyPoints: Think like an engineer - abstraction helps you see systems in parts
Focus on what something does rather than how it does it
Essential for effective AI prompting and system design

examples.title: Car Analogy
examples.description: You press the gas pedal → the car moves. You don't need to understand the engine, pistons, or combustion to drive.

examples.title: Map Analogy
examples.description: A subway map doesn't show real geography. It shows only the routes and stops - the complexity is abstracted into a usable model.

content.introduction: Most things you build - websites, tools, automations - follow a pattern. They're built in layers.
When working with AI assistants, you're giving instructions for each layer. With abstraction, you're speaking the AI's language.

examples.prompt: I want a form (UI) that lets people upload a file (Component), and when they click submit (Logic), it saves the file to Dropbox and sends me a Slack message (Architecture).
examples.explanation: This prompt clearly describes each layer of the system

examples.prompt: When user clicks the button, trigger a modal with pre-filled data and send an API request to update the backend.
examples.explanation: Describes the interaction flow across different layers

modules.title: Data Structures
modules.description: Learn how to organize information for AI tools and automations

content.introduction: Data structures are ways to organize information so it can be stored, used, and passed around - like organizing groceries in a bag so you can carry them properly.
keyPoints: Organization matters - don't put eggs at the bottom of the bag
Essential for communicating with AI tools and APIs

content.analogy: A grocery list - one item after another
content.definition: An ordered list of items where each item has a position

interactive.instructions: Try adding or removing items from this list

content.analogy: A labeled drawer with named compartments
content.definition: A collection of key-value pairs where each item has a name and value

interactive.instructions: Try modifying the keys and values

content.introduction: JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) is a universal format that combines lists and objects. It's how most modern systems communicate.
keyPoints: Used by APIs, automation tools, and AI systems

examples.title: Course Data
examples.explanation: Notice how this combines objects (course info) with arrays (list of modules)

trees.analogy: A folder system or family tree
trees.definition: A branching structure with parent-child relationships

graphs.analogy: A subway map or social network
graphs.definition: A network of connected points (nodes) with relationships (edges)

modules.title: APIs and Communication
modules.description: Understand how software talks to software

content.analogy: APIs are like waiters in a restaurant - you tell the waiter what you want, they bring it from the kitchen
content.definition: Application Programming Interface - how different software systems communicate
keyPoints: You send a request with what you want
You get back a response with the data

examples.request: Give me the weather for NYC

modules.title: Client vs Server
modules.description: Understanding who does what in web applications

content.introduction: The client is what users see. The server is the brain doing work behind the scenes.

client.description: The website, form, or app on your screen

server.description: Where the logic happens - saving info, running AI models, sending emails
